article:
A 'fen' is one of the six main types of wetland and one of two types of mire
(the other being a bog). It is usually fed by mineral-rich surface water or
groundwater. Godwin, K. S., Shallenberger, J., Leopold, D. J., and Bedford,
B. L. (2002). Linking landscape properties to local hydrogeologic gradients and
plant species occurrence in New York fens: a hydrogeologic setting (HGS)
framework. Wetlands, 22, 722â37. Fens are characterised by their water
chemistry, which is neutral or alkaline, with relatively high dissolved mineral
levels but few other plant nutrients. They are usually dominated by grasses and
sedges, and typically have brown mosses in general including Scorpidium or
Drepanocladus. Keddy, P.A. 2010. Wetland Ecology: Principles and
Conservation (2nd edition). Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK. p.8
Fens frequently have a high diversity of other plant species including
carnivorous plants such as [[Pinguicula]]. Wheeler, B. D. and Giller, K. E.
(1982). Species richness of herbaceous fen vegetation in Broadland, Norfolk in
relation to the quantity of above-ground plant material. Journal of Ecology, 70,
179â200. Keddy, P.A. 2010. Wetland Ecology: Principles and
Conservation (2nd edition). Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK. Chapter
9. They may also occur along large lakes and rivers where seasonal changes
in water level maintain wet soils with few woody plants. Charlton, D. L. and
Hilts, S. (1989). Quantitative evaluation of fen ecosystems on the Bruce
Peninsula. In Ontario Wetlands: Inertia or Momentum, eds. M. J. Bardecki and N.
Patterson, pp. 339â54. Proceedings of Conference, Ryerson Polytechnical
Institute, Toronto, Oct 21â22, 1988. Toronto, ON: Federation of Ontario
Naturalists. The distribution of individual species of fen plants is often
closely connected to water regimes and nutrient concentrations. Slack, N.
G., Vitt, D. H., and Horton, D. G. (1980). Vegetation gradients of
minerotrophically rich fens in western Alberta. Canadian Journal of Botany, 58,
330â50. Schroder, H. K., Andersen, H. E., Kiehl, K., and Kenkel, N.
(2005). Rejecting the mean: estimating the response of fen plant species to
environmental factors by non-linear quantile regression. Journal of Vegetation
Science, 16, 373â82.

Fens have a characteristic set of plant species, which sometimes provide the
best indicators of environmental conditions. For example, fen indicator species
in New York include ''Carex flava'', [[Cladium]] mariscoides, Potentilla
fruticosa, [[Pogonia ophioglossoides]] and [[Parnassia]] glauca. Godwin, K.
S., Shallenberger, J., Leopold, D. J., and Bedford, B. L. (2002). Linking
landscape properties to local hydrogeologic gradients and plant species
occurrence in New York fens: a hydrogeologic setting (HGS) framework. Wetlands,
22, 722â37. Table 3.

Fens are distinguished from bogs, which are acidic, low in minerals, and usually
dominated by sedges and shrubs, along with abundant mosses in the genus
[[Sphagnum]]. Keddy, P.A. 2010. Wetland Ecology: Principles and Conservation
(2nd edition). Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK. p.8

Fens have been damaged in the past by land drainage, and also by peat
cutting. Sheail, J. and Wells, T. C. E. (1983). The Fenlands of
Huntingdonshire, England: a case study in catastrophic change. In Ecosystems of
the World, Vol. 4B, Mires: Swamp, Bog, Fen and Moor â Regional Studies, ed. A.
J. P. Gore, pp. 375â93. Amsterdam, the Netherlands: Elsevier. Some are now
being carefully restored with modern management methods. Keddy, P.A. 2010.
Wetland Ecology: Principles and Conservation (2nd edition). Cambridge University
Press, Cambridge, UK. Chapter 13. The principal challenges are to restore
natural water flow regimes, to maintain the quality of water, and to prevent
invasion by woody plants.
